output.answer:
The country is divided up into electoral districts or 'seats'. [Here's a map of seats.](_URL_0_).

In each of those areas, you have a little election. Whichever candidate gets the most votes there gets that seat. Then whichever party gets the most seats wins the election.

Imagine if you would that we had three parties - Red, Blue, and Gold. Now, 45% of people want to vote Gold, but by a happenstance of chance these people are spread evenly across the country, so that each district has 45% for Gold. We'll say that Blue is very popular in greater London and the Red is popular everywhere else, with 55% of the vote in their home areas and 0% elsewhere.

Neither Red nor Blue are the most popular party, nor do they support the country as a whole, but they will claim 100% of the seats between them. This is a 'known bug' with the parliamentary democracy system. Usually it works out because usually there is a majority party who has a majority of the popular vote, but not always.

A suggested 'patch' is called proportional representation. In that system, regional representation would either be eliminated entirely or given it's own, weaker house, like the House of Lords.

The chief objection to this is that it will always lead to a coalition government, and that coalition governments aren't actually more representative. Typically, you get the largest party (in this case, Conservatives with 37% of the popular vote) needing to find another 14% to form a government. So they'd try to form a coalition with UKIP, but they'd still need a third party onboard. But who? Labour? Green? No, it would have to be the SNP.

So your outcome government would be a conservative party that relied on maintaining total support from SNP and UKIP. That would be a coalition that would be far to the right of the current one and would have to give preferential treatment to Scotland, which would irk the conservatives own voters. The end result would be an election much sooner.

It may still be a more fair system, but try to understand that it will always produce coalitions, and that coalitions can do crazy things. It gives extremist views a bigger role in government - Israel, for example, was forced to give special rights to the ultra-orthodox community to maintain it's current coalition, exempting them from a number of laws. Think on that possibility before you decide if having UKIP occasionally in a coalition is worth it.

TL;DR version: each constituency (small area of the country) elects one MP: whichever one gets the most votes. So if party A gets 49% in every constituency, and party B gets 51% in every constituency, then party A will get no MPs.

The other way of failing to win seats is to have all of your voters in one constituency: even if they all vote for you, you're only ever getting one MP.

Edit: I don't literally mean "all your voters in one constituency," I mean large majorities in a smallish number of constituencies.

UKIP mainly had the first problem of being too spread out. They're not the only party to have this problem: the system favours the bigger parties.

The UK is divided into 650 constituencies. All parties (Conservatives, Labour, Liberal Democrats etc), and independents, have a candidate that the voters of each constituency must choose to be their member of parliament. The party with the most elected candidates becomes the Government of the UK. The leader of that party becomes the Prime Minister.

Incidentally; it is entirely possible for a party to be elected to govern the UK even though their leader may not win the seat in their constituency.

It's not proportional, each election is winner take all.  So a party that gets 2nd place in a large number of elections and first in very few can get a large share of the vote (right up to 49.9% overall, if the other party gets 50.1% in each race), but very few seats.

question: How do electio s work in the UK I watched the results and it didnt seem proportional at all.
long_answers:
The country is divided up into electoral districts or 'seats'. [Here's a map of seats.](_URL_0_).

In each of those areas, you have a little election. Whichever candidate gets the most votes there gets that seat. Then whichever party gets the most seats wins the election.

Imagine if you would that we had three parties - Red, Blue, and Gold. Now, 45% of people want to vote Gold, but by a happenstance of chance these people are spread evenly across the country, so that each district has 45% for Gold. We'll say that Blue is very popular in greater London and the Red is popular everywhere else, with 55% of the vote in their home areas and 0% elsewhere.

Neither Red nor Blue are the most popular party, nor do they support the country as a whole, but they will claim 100% of the seats between them. This is a 'known bug' with the parliamentary democracy system. Usually it works out because usually there is a majority party who has a majority of the popular vote, but not always.

A suggested 'patch' is called proportional representation. In that system, regional representation would either be eliminated entirely or given it's own, weaker house, like the House of Lords.

The chief objection to this is that it will always lead to a coalition government, and that coalition governments aren't actually more representative. Typically, you get the largest party (in this case, Conservatives with 37% of the popular vote) needing to find another 14% to form a government. So they'd try to form a coalition with UKIP, but they'd still need a third party onboard. But who? Labour? Green? No, it would have to be the SNP.

So your outcome government would be a conservative party that relied on maintaining total support from SNP and UKIP. That would be a coalition that would be far to the right of the current one and would have to give preferential treatment to Scotland, which would irk the conservatives own voters. The end result would be an election much sooner.

It may still be a more fair system, but try to understand that it will always produce coalitions, and that coalitions can do crazy things. It gives extremist views a bigger role in government - Israel, for example, was forced to give special rights to the ultra-orthodox community to maintain it's current coalition, exempting them from a number of laws. Think on that possibility before you decide if having UKIP occasionally in a coalition is worth it.

llama13b_without_search_answer:
In the United Kingdom, elections are held to elect members of parliament (MPs) to the House of Commons, which is the lower house of the bicameral Parliament. The UK uses a first-past-the-post (FPTP) electoral system, where each constituency elects one MP, and the candidate with the most votes in that constituency wins the seat.

The FPTP system is a plurality system, meaning that the candidate with the most votes in a constituency wins, even if they do not have a majority of the total votes cast in the constituency. This means that it is possible for a party to win a majority of seats in the House of Commons with less than 50% of the total vote.

In the 2019 UK general election, the Conservative Party, led by Boris Johnson, won a majority of seats in the House of Commons with only 43.6% of the total vote. The Labour Party, led by Jeremy Corbyn, received 41.7% of the total vote, but won fewer seats than the Conservatives.

One reason why the results of the election may not have seemed proportional is that the UK has a number of small political parties, including the Liberal Democrats, the Scottish National Party (SNP), and the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which can split the vote and make it more difficult for larger parties to win a majority of seats. Additionally, the UK has a number of three-party and four-party battles in some constituencies, which can also lead to non-proportional results.

It's worth noting that there are alternative electoral systems that are designed to produce more proportional results, such as proportional representation (PR) systems, which are used in many other countries around the world. Under PR systems, seats are allocated to parties based on their share of the total vote, rather than the winner-takes-all approach used in FPTP systems. However, the UK has traditionally used FPTP systems for its national elections, and there is no current plan to switch to a PR system.

question: who was the only justice to be impeached
llama13b_without_search_answer:
The only Supreme Court Justice to be impeached was Samuel Chase. He was impeached by the House of Representatives in 1804, during the presidency of Thomas Jefferson, on charges of political bias and judicial misconduct. Chase had been a prominent Federalist and had been appointed to the Supreme Court by President George Washington. However, he became a target of criticism from Jefferson and his Democratic-Republican Party, who accused him of being overly sympathetic to the Federalist Party and of attempting to obstruct their agenda.

The impeachment trial was held in the Senate in 1805, with Chief Justice John Marshall presiding. After a lengthy trial, Chase was acquitted of all charges by a vote of 52-0. The acquittal was largely due to the strong defense presented by Chase's legal team, which argued that the charges were politically motivated and violated the principles of judicial independence.

Although Chase was acquitted, the impeachment process had a lasting impact on his career and reputation. He continued to serve on the Supreme Court until his death in 1811, but he was never fully rehabilitated in the eyes of his political opponents. The impeachment of Samuel Chase remains one of the most significant events in the history of the Supreme Court and serves as a cautionary tale about the dangers of political interference in the judiciary.

question: what type of genre is diary of a wimpy kid
llama13b_without_search_answer:
The "Diary of a Wimpy Kid" series is a popular children's book series written by Jeff Kinney. The series is classified as a humoristic and semi-autobiographical novel, but it also incorporates elements of coming-of-age, school, and family life.

The books are written in a diary format, with the main character, Greg Heffley, narrating his experiences and struggles as a middle school student. The series is known for its relatable humor, witty illustrations, and lighthearted storytelling, making it a favorite among children and young adults.

Some of the key genres that the "Diary of a Wimpy Kid" series belongs to include:

1. Humoristic fiction: The series is primarily known for its humorous tone and lighthearted storytelling, making it a great choice for readers looking for a funny and entertaining read.
2. Coming-of-age: The series follows the main character, Greg Heffley, as he navigates the challenges of middle school and adolescence, making it a classic coming-of-age story.
3. School stories: The series is set in a middle school environment, and many of the stories revolve around Greg's experiences in school, making it a school story.
4. Family life: The series also explores the Heffley family's dynamics and their daily life, adding a domestic element to the story.
5. Semi-autobiographical: Jeff Kinney, the author, has stated that the series is based on his own childhood experiences, making it semi-autobiographical.

Overall, the "Diary of a Wimpy Kid" series is a unique blend of humor, coming-of-age, school, family life, and semi-autobiographical elements, making it a beloved and relatable series for many readers.

paragraphs.title: Chair of the Federal Reserve
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The chair is chosen by the President of the United States from among the members of the Board of Governors; and serves for four - year - terms after appointment. A chair may be appointed for several consecutive terms. William Martin was the longest serving chair, holding the position from 1951 to 1970.

paragraphs.title: Central Board of Film Certification
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The Board consists of 25 other non-official members and a Chairperson (all of whom are appointed by Central Government). Prasoon Joshi currently presides the board, being appointed as the 28th Chairperson of the Board on 11 August 2017, after the ouster of Pahlaj Nihalani, who was preceded by Leela Samson who had resigned after the CBFC's rejection of a certificate for the film MSG: Messenger of God was overturned by an appellate tribunal. Earlier, Leela Samson had succeeded Sharmila Tagore, who was the longest continuous running Chairperson in the history. Nihalani was the 27th Chairperson after the Board's establishment. His appointment was highly controversial given his propensity for censoring films instead of merely certifying them.

paragraphs.title: Financial Accounting Standards Board
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) is a private, non-profit organization standard setting body whose primary purpose is to establish and improve generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) within the United States in the public's interest. The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) designated the FASB as the organization responsible for setting accounting standards for public companies in the U.S. The FASB replaced the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants' (AICPA) Accounting Principles Board (APB) on July 1, 1973.

paragraphs.title: Sitoh Yih Pin
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Sitoh Yih Pin (, born 2 December 1963) is a Singaporean politician from the Singapore People's Action Party. He is the Member of Parliament (MP) for the Potong Pasir Single Member Constituency (Potong Pasir SMC). Sitoh is currently the Chairman of Nexia TS Public Accounting Corporation, an accounting firm in Singapore.

paragraphs.title: Maurice Canning Wilks
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Maurice Canning Wilks (1910–1984) was an Irish landscape painter. Born in Belfast in 1910 to a linen designer, he was educated in Belfast at the Malone Public School and attended evening classes at the Belfast College of Art. While attending college he was awarded the Dunville Scholarship allowing him to attend day classes. He went on to exhibit at the Royal Hibernian Academy (RHA) in Dublin where he would one day become an associate member. He was also elected a full member of the Royal Ulster Academy (RUA).

paragraphs.title: Ip Man (film)
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Jin Shanzhao and his men inform the Japanese soldiers of Ip's connection to the cotton mill. The Japanese charge into the cotton mill and takes Ip. Ip tells Chow to take his wife and son away for protection. Miura tells Ip that his life will be spared if he agrees to instruct the Japanese soldiers in martial arts. Ip refuses and challenges Miura to a match, which Miura accepts, both because of his love for martial arts and because refusing the challenge would be a humiliation to the Japanese. The match between Ip and Miura is held in public in Foshan's square. Sato tells Ip that his life will be spared if he lets the general win. At first, the two fighters seem equally matched, but Ip's impeccable defense, relentless and direct blows allow him to eventually overwhelm Miura, inflicting a severe beating on him.

paragraphs.title: Indian Accounting Standards
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Indian Accounting Standard (abbreviated as Ind - AS) is the Accounting standard adopted by companies in India and issued under the supervison of Accounting Standards Board (ASB) which was constituted as a body in the year 1977. ASB is a committee under Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) which consists of representatives from government department, academicians, other professional bodies viz. ICAI, representatives from ASSOCHAM, CII, FICCI, etc.

paragraphs.title: Public Company Accounting Oversight Board
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The PCAOB has five Board members, including a Chairman, each of whom is appointed by the SEC, after consultation with the Chairman of the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Secretary of the Treasury. Two Board members must be Certified Public Accountants. If the PCAOB Chairman is one of them, he or she may not have been a practicing CPA for at least five years prior to being appointed to the board. Each member serves full - time, for staggered five - year terms. The Board's budget, approved by the SEC each year, is funded by fees paid by the companies and broker - dealers who rely on the audit firms overseen by the Board. The organization has a staff of about 800 and offices in 11 states in addition to its headquarters in Washington.

paragraphs.title: Auditor's report
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The auditor's report on the financial statements typically provides very limited details on the procedures and findings of the audit. In contrast, auditors provide much more detail to the board of directors or to the audit committee of the board. Beginning in 2002, many countries have tasked the audit committee with primary responsibility over the audit. For example, in the United States, section 204 of the Sarbanes - Oxley Act passed in 2002 required auditors to communicate certain information to audit committees, which were required to be entirely independent, and also made the audit committee responsible for the auditor's hiring. In August 2012, the U.S. Public Company Accounting Oversight Board finalized Auditing Standard No. 16, which requires additional communications to the audit committee.

paragraphs.title: Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales (ICAEW) was established by royal charter in 1880. It has over 147,000 members. Over 15,000 of these members live and work outside the UK. In 2015, 8,256 students joined ICAEW - the highest ever figure. 82 of FTSE 100 (the leading UK) companies have an ICAEW Chartered Accountant on the board.

paragraphs.title: Oscar Munoz (executive)
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Oscar Munoz (born January 1959) is an American businessman. He was named president and chief executive officer (CEO) of United Airlines on September 8, 2015. At the time of this appointment, Munoz had been serving as a member of the board of directors of parent company United Continental Holdings (UCH) since its formation with the 2010 merger between United and Continental. Munoz had been a member of Continental's board of directors since 2004.

paragraphs.title: Pub
paragraphs.paragraph_text: By the 20th century, the saloon, or lounge bar, had become a middle-class room[citation needed]—carpets on the floor, cushions on the seats, and a penny or two on the prices,[citation needed] while the public bar, or tap room, remained working class with bare boards, sometimes with sawdust to absorb the spitting and spillages (known as "spit and sawdust"), hard bench seats, and cheap beer[citation needed]. This bar was known as the four-ale bar from the days when the cheapest beer served there cost 4 pence (4d) a quart.[citation needed]

paragraphs.title: Gary Scherer
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Gary Scherer is a Republican member of the Ohio House of Representatives for the 92nd district, which includes Fayette County, as well as portions of Pickaway and Ross counties. He was appointed in April 2012 to replace Bob Peterson, who was appointed to the Ohio Senate. Scherer has a degree in accounting from Ohio State University, and worked as an accountant and businessman before becoming a Representative. He is married with three children.

paragraphs.title: IP Multimedia Subsystem
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The IP Multimedia Subsystem or IP Multimedia Core Network Subsystem (IMS) is an architectural framework for delivering IP multimedia services. Historically, mobile phones have provided voice call services over a circuit - switched - style network, rather than strictly over an IP packet - switched network. Alternative methods of delivering voice (VoIP) or other multimedia services have become available on smartphones, but they have not become standardized across the industry. IMS is an architectural framework to provide such standardization.

paragraphs.title: Nonprofit organization
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Canada also permits a variety of charities (including public and private foundations). Charitable status is granted by the Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) upon application by a nonprofit; charities are allowed to issue income tax receipts to donors, must spend a certain percentage of their assets (including cash, investments and fixed assets) and file annual reports in order to maintain their charitable status. In determining whether an organization can become a charity, CRA applies a common law test to its stated objects and activities. These must be:

paragraphs.title: Intellectual property
paragraphs.paragraph_text: In 2013 the United States Patent & Trademark Office approximated that the worth of intellectual property to the U.S. economy is more than US$5 trillion and creates employment for an estimated 18 million American people. The value of intellectual property is considered similarly high in other developed nations, such as those in the European Union. In the UK, IP has become a recognised asset class for use in pension-led funding and other types of business finance. However, in 2013, the UK Intellectual Property Office stated: "There are millions of intangible business assets whose value is either not being leveraged at all, or only being leveraged inadvertently".

paragraphs.title: Committee of Public Safety
paragraphs.paragraph_text: On 27 July 1793, Maximilien Robespierre was elected to the Committee. At this time, the Committee was entering a more powerful and active phase, which would see it become a de facto dictatorship alongside its powerful partner, the Committee of General Security. The role of the Committee of Public Safety included the governance of the war (including the appointment of generals), the appointing of judges and juries for the Revolutionary Tribunal, the provisioning of the armies and the public, the maintenance of public order, and oversight of the state bureaucracy.

paragraphs.title: Dell
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The board consists of nine directors. Michael Dell, the founder of the company, serves as chairman of the board and chief executive officer. Other board members include Don Carty, William Gray, Judy Lewent, Klaus Luft, Alex Mandl, Michael A. Miles, and Sam Nunn. Shareholders elect the nine board members at meetings, and those board members who do not get a majority of votes must submit a resignation to the board, which will subsequently choose whether or not to accept the resignation. The board of directors usually sets up five committees having oversight over specific matters. These committees include the Audit Committee, which handles accounting issues, including auditing and reporting; the Compensation Committee, which approves compensation for the CEO and other employees of the company; the Finance Committee, which handles financial matters such as proposed mergers and acquisitions; the Governance and Nominating Committee, which handles various corporate matters (including nomination of the board); and the Antitrust Compliance Committee, which attempts to prevent company practices from violating antitrust laws.[citation needed]

paragraphs.title: Indian Accounting Standards
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Indian Accounting Standard (abbreviated as Ind - AS) is the Accounting standard adopted by companies in India and issued under the supervision and control of Accounting Standards Board (ASB), which was constituted as a body in the year 1977. ASB is a committee under Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI) which consists of representatives from government department, academicians, other professional bodies viz. ICAI, representatives from ASSOCHAM, CII, FICCI, etc.

paragraphs.title: Securities commission
paragraphs.paragraph_text: There is no common name for securities commission or financial regulatory agency in each country. Naming has become more complicated as some governments have consolidated or merged organisations and given them a wider remit. They sometimes contain the term securities and commission. Such as the Securities and Exchange Commission of the US or Securities and Futures Commission (Hong Kong). A number also have names based on Financial Authority, such as the Financial Services Authority of the UK or Financial Supervisory Authority (Sweden) or variations such as the Financial Services Agency (Japan).

Carrots sold frozen are actually more fresh than "fresh" carrots because they're frozen very soon after harvest rather than being transported around and sitting in warehouses for a while before reaching the shelf.

You should find that a freshly picked carrot is similar in taste and texture to a frozen one from the same farm.
llama13b_without_search_answer:
Frozen carrots can taste different from fresh carrots due to several reasons:

1. Freezing process: During the freezing process, the water inside the carrots forms ice crystals, which can cause the cells of the vegetable to rupture and release their contents. This can result in a softer, less crunchy texture and a slightly different flavor.
2. Blanching: To preserve the color and texture of frozen carrots, they are often blanched before freezing. Blanching involves briefly boiling or steaming the carrots to inactivate enzymes that can cause spoilage and discoloration. This process can affect the flavor and texture of the carrots.
3. Storage conditions: Frozen carrots are typically stored at very low temperatures, which can affect their flavor and texture. Prolonged storage can cause the carrots to develop off-flavors or become soft and mushy.
4. Variety: Different varieties of carrots have different flavor profiles and textures. Frozen carrots may be made from a specific variety that is bred for its ability to freeze well, rather than its flavor or texture.
5. Preparation method: The way frozen carrots are prepared can also affect their flavor and texture. For example, if they are cooked before freezing, they may have a softer, more cooked flavor than fresh carrots.
6. Thawing and reheating: When frozen carrots are thawed and reheated, they may not retain their original texture and flavor. They may become mushy or develop an unpleasant texture.
7. Additives: Some frozen carrot products may contain additives such as preservatives, flavor enhancers, or anti-browning agents, which can affect the flavor and texture of the carrots.

Overall, the combination of these factors can result in frozen carrots tasting different from fresh carrots. However, many people find that frozen carrots still have a good flavor and texture, especially when used in certain dishes like soups, stews, and casseroles.

qa_pairs.question: Which government created the quote keep calm and carry on?
qa_pairs.context: Keep Calm and Carry On is a motivational poster produced by the British government in 1939 in preparation for World War II. The poster was intended to raise the morale of the British public, threatened with widely predicted mass air attacks on major cities. Although 2.45 million copies were printed, and although the Blitz did in fact take place, the poster was only rarely publicly displayed and was little known until a copy was rediscovered in 2000 at Barter Books, a bookshop in Alnwick. It has since been re-issued by a number of private companies, and has been used as the decorative theme for a range of products.

qa_pairs.question: Which ministry created the quote keep calm and carry on?
qa_pairs.context: The "Keep Calm and Carry On" poster was designed by the Ministry of Information during the period of 27 June to 6 July 1939. It was produced as part of a series of three "Home Publicity" posters (the others read "Your "Courage," Your "Cheerfulness," Your "Resolution Will Bring Us Victory"" and ""Freedom Is in Peril / Defend It With All Your Might""). Each poster showed the slogan under a representation of a "Tudor Crown" (a symbol of the state). They were intended to be distributed to strengthen morale in the event of a wartime disaster, such as mass bombing of major cities using high explosives and poison gas, which was widely expected within hours of an outbreak of war.

annotations.long_answer: The "Keep Calm and Carry On" quote originated as a motivational poster designed by the Ministry of Information. It was produced by the British government in 1939 in preparation for World War II. Since then, it has since been used as the decorative quote for a range of products.

The poster was designed by the Ministry of Information and was intended to boost morale and encourage people to remain calm and carry on with their daily lives despite the challenges and hardships of the war.

The poster was created by the artist Sir Ernest H. Shepard, who was commissioned by the government to create a series of posters to promote morale and support for the war effort. The poster featured a simple message in bold font, "Keep Calm and Carry On," along with an image of a stiff-upper-lip British citizen carrying a load of books or other items.

The poster was first distributed in 1939, just before the outbreak of World War II, and it quickly became a popular slogan and symbol of British determination and resilience during the war. It was reprinted and distributed widely throughout the UK, and it remains a well-known and iconic image of British culture and history.

While the phrase "Keep Calm and Carry On" was not attributed to any specific person or organization at the time it was created, it has since become associated with the spirit of British determination and resilience during times of adversity.

paragraphs.title: The American President
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The American President is a 1995 American romantic comedy-drama film directed by Rob Reiner and written by Aaron Sorkin. The film stars Michael Douglas, Annette Bening, Martin Sheen, Michael J. Fox, and Richard Dreyfuss. In the film, President Andrew Shepherd (Douglas) is a widower who pursues a relationship with environmental lobbyist Sydney Ellen Wade (Bening) – who has just moved to Washington, D.C. – while at the same time attempting to win the passage of a crime control bill during a re-election year.

paragraphs.title: Myanmar
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The Rohingya people have consistently faced human rights abuses by the Burmese regime that has refused to acknowledge them as Burmese citizens (despite some of them having lived in Burma for over three generations)—the Rohingya have been denied Burmese citizenship since the enactment of a 1982 citizenship law. The law created three categories of citizenship: citizenship, associate citizenship, and naturalised citizenship. Citizenship is given to those who belong to one of the national races such as Kachin, Kayah (Karenni), Karen, Chin, Burman, Mon, Rakhine, Shan, Kaman, or Zerbadee. Associate citizenship is given to those who cannot prove their ancestors settled in Myanmar before 1823, but can prove they have one grandparent, or pre-1823 ancestor, who was a citizen of another country, as well as people who applied for citizenship in 1948 and qualified then by those laws. Naturalized citizenship is only given to those who have at least one parent with one of these types of Burmese citizenship or can provide "conclusive evidence" that their parents entered and resided in Burma prior to independence in 1948. The Burmese regime has attempted to forcibly expel Rohingya and bring in non-Rohingyas to replace them—this policy has resulted in the expulsion of approximately half of the 800,000 Rohingya from Burma, while the Rohingya people have been described as "among the world's least wanted" and "one of the world's most persecuted minorities." But the origin of ‘most persecuted minority’ statement is unclear.

paragraphs.title: List of first overall NBA draft picks
paragraphs.paragraph_text: China's Yao Ming (2002) and Italy's Andrea Bargnani (2006) are the only two players without competitive experience in the United States to be drafted first overall. Eleven other international players with U.S. college experience have been drafted first overall -- Mychal Thompson (Bahamas) in 1978, Hakeem Olajuwon (Nigeria) in 1984, Patrick Ewing (Jamaica) in 1985, Tim Duncan (U.S. Virgin Islands) in 1997, Michael Olowokandi (Nigeria) in 1998, Andrew Bogut (Australia) in 2005, Kyrie Irving (Australia) in 2011, Anthony Bennett (Canada) in 2013, Andrew Wiggins (Canada) in 2014, Ben Simmons (Australia) in 2016, and Deandre Ayton (Bahamas) in 2018. Duncan is an American citizen, but is considered an ``international ''player by the NBA because he was not born in one of the fifty states or the District of Columbia. Ewing had dual Jamaican - American citizenship when he was drafted and Irving and Simmons had dual Australian - American citizenship when they were drafted.

paragraphs.title: Nigeria
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Since 2002, the North East of the country has seen sectarian violence by Boko Haram, an Islamist movement that seeks to abolish the secular system of government and establish Sharia law. Nigerian President Goodluck Jonathan in May 2014 claimed that Boko Haram attacks have left at least 12,000 people dead and 8,000 people crippled. At the same time, neighbouring countries, Benin, Chad, Cameroon and Niger joined Nigeria in a united effort to combat Boko Haram in the aftermath of a world media highlighted kidnapping of 276 schoolgirls and the spread of Boko Haram attacks to these countries.

paragraphs.title: Sara Tancredi
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Two episodes later, Sara returns in ``The Message ''. She reunites with Michael in Evansville, Indiana in`` Chicago''. Together with the brothers, Sara travels to Chicago where her father has hidden the audio file that can help prove Lincoln's innocence. On the train to Chicago, Sara admits to Michael that she has fallen in love with him, and they kiss. Later in the episode, Michael admits he has fallen in love with her. Michael, Sara and Lincoln eventually retrieve the audio file but discover that it's not legally valid as evidence. They decide to use it to blackmail President Reynolds for a presidential pardon instead. When this fails, Michael and Lincoln are forced to leave the country. When Sara realizes she is being tailed by the FBI, she surrenders herself in order to let the brothers escape. Sara is then faced with a 12 - year prison sentence but as she is about to plead guilty, Kellerman comes forward to testify on her behalf. His testimony exonerates Sara and Lincoln in ``Sona '', and Sara reunites with the brothers in Panama and tells them of the news. However, when Agent Kim suddenly appears and tries to kill Lincoln and capture Michael, Sara shoots Kim in the chest. With nowhere to run, Michael and Sara surrender themselves to the Panamanian police but to Sara's surprise, Michael confesses to Kim's killing instead of her. She is last seen in a crowd by Lincoln.

paragraphs.title: History of laws concerning immigration and naturalization in the United States
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Pursuant to this power, Congress in 1790 passed the first naturalization law for the United States, the Naturalization Act of 1790. The law enabled those who had resided in the country for two years and had kept their current state of residence for a year to apply for citizenship. However it restricted naturalization to ``free white persons ''of`` good moral character''.

paragraphs.title: President of India
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Supreme Court shall inquire and decide regarding all doubts and disputes arising out of or in connection with the election of a President per Article 71 (1) of the constitution. Supreme Court can remove the president for the electoral malpractices or upon being not eligible to be Lok Sabha member under the Representation of the People Act, 1951. Subject to Article 71 (3), Parliament made applicable rules / procedure to petition the Supreme Court for resolving the disputes only that arise during the election process of the president but not the doubts that arise from his unconstitutional actions / deeds or changing Indian citizenship during the tenure of president which may violate the requisite election qualifications.

question: The Boston Tea Party, where tea was tipped into the harbour to protest taxation, precipitated what historical event?

llama13b_without_search_answer:
The Boston Tea Party, which took place on December 16, 1773, was a key event in the lead-up to the American Revolution. It was a protest against taxation by the British government on the American colonies, and it helped to precipitate the Revolutionary War.

The Boston Tea Party was a response to the Tea Act, which had been passed by the British Parliament in 1773. The Tea Act granted a monopoly on the importation of tea to the East India Company, and it allowed the company to sell tea directly to the colonies, bypassing local merchants. The colonists were angry about the taxes imposed on tea and the fact that they had no representation in Parliament.

On the night of December 16, a group of colonists, disguised as Native Americans, boarded three British ships that were docked in Boston Harbor. They threw 342 chests of tea into the water, which amounted to over 92,000 pounds of tea. The event became known as the Boston Tea Party and it was a significant act of defiance against British rule.

The Boston Tea Party had several consequences. The British government responded by passing a series of laws known as the Coercive Acts, which were designed to punish the colonists for their actions. These laws included the closure of the port of Boston, the dissolution of the Massachusetts colonial government, and the quartering of British soldiers in the homes of colonists. These actions further inflamed tensions between the colonists and the British government, and they contributed to the outbreak of the Revolutionary War in 1775.

paragraphs.title: All My Ex's Live in Texas
paragraphs.paragraph_text: ``All My Ex's Live In Texas ''is a song written by Sanger D. Shafer and Linda J. Shafer, and recorded by American country singer George Strait. It was released in April 1987 as the second single from Strait's album Ocean Front Property.`` All My Ex's Live In Texas'' was nominated for Best Male Country Vocal Performance at the 1988 Grammy Awards.

paragraphs.title: Saginaw, Michigan (song)
paragraphs.paragraph_text: ``Saginaw, Michigan ''is a 1964 song performed by Lefty Frizzell. The single was Lefty Frizzell's sixth and final number one on the U.S. country chart.`` Saginaw, Michigan'' spent a total of twenty - three weeks on the country chart and peaked at number eighty - five on the Billboard Hot 100. The song earned Lefty Frizzell a Grammy nomination.

paragraphs.title: I'd Be Better Off (In a Pine Box)
paragraphs.paragraph_text: ``I'd Be Better Off (In a Pine Box) ''is the title of a debut single written by Johnny MacRae and Steve Clark, and recorded by American country music artist Doug Stone. It was released in February 1990 as the first single from his self titled debut album. It peaked at # 4 on the Billboard Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart and # 5 on The Canadian RPM Tracks chart. It was also nominated for a Grammy Award for Best Male Country Vocal Performance.

paragraphs.title: Mama Spank
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Mama Spank is a song written and recorded by American country music artist Liz Anderson. The song peaked at number five on U.S. Billboards Hot Country Singles chart and became the most successful record of Anderson's recording career and went on to earn Anderson a Grammy nomination for Best Female Country Vocal Performance competing against Skeeter Davis, Connie Smith, Dottie West, and the ultimate winner, Tammy Wynette.

paragraphs.title: I'm Not Supposed to Love You Anymore
paragraphs.paragraph_text: "I'm Not Supposed to Love You Anymore" is a song co-written by Skip Ewing and Donny Kees, and performed by American country music singer Bryan White. It was released in February 1996 as the first single from his album "Between Now and Forever". The song peaked at number 4 on the U.S. country chart and at number 2 on the Canadian country chart. It also peaked at number 1 on the Bubbling Under Hot 100 chart.

paragraphs.title: How Long Will My Baby Be Gone
paragraphs.paragraph_text: "How Long Will My Baby Be Gone" is a 1968 song written and recorded by Buck Owens. "How Long Will My Baby Be Gone" was the last of eight number ones on the country chart in a row for Buck Owens. The single spent a single week at number one and a total of thirteen weeks on the country chart. The song is still performed at the Country Bear Jamboree attraction at certain Disney parks.

paragraphs.title: Venezuela (album)
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Venezuela is the name of a 33-RPM LP album by Venezuelan composer/arranger/conductor Aldemaro Romero, released in 1958, under contract with RCA Victor.

paragraphs.title: That'd Be Alright
paragraphs.paragraph_text: "That'd Be Alright" is a song written by Tia Sillers, Tim Nichols and Mark D. Sanders, and performed by American country music artist Alan Jackson. It was released in December 2002 as the fourth and final single his album "Drive". The song reached the Top 5 on the U.S. "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart, peaking at number 2.

paragraphs.title: Maybe We Should Just Sleep on It
paragraphs.paragraph_text: "Maybe We Should Just Sleep on It" is a song written by Jerry Laseter and Kerry Kurt Phillips, and performed by American country music artist Tim McGraw. It was released in October 1996 as the fifth and final single from his third studio album "All I Want" (1995). It peaked at number 4 on the United States "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart, while it reached number one on the "RPM" Country Tracks chart in Canada.

It is close to the border with Colombia, and the area's main economic activity is cattle raising. On 16 August 2005 West Caribbean Airways Flight 708, en route from Panama City to Fort-de-France, stalled and crashed in a mountainous area of the municipality, killing all 160 people on board.

paragraphs.title: It's a Business Doing Pleasure with You

paragraphs.paragraph_text: "People Are Crazy" is a song written by Bobby Braddock and Troy Jones and recorded by American country music singer Billy Currington. It was released in March 2009 as the second single from Currington’s 2008 album "Little Bit of Everything". The song became Currington's third number one hit on the US "Billboard" Hot Country Songs chart. On December 2, 2009, the song was nominated for two Grammy Awards for Best Male Country Vocal Performance and Best Country Song. The song was also nominated for "Song of the Year" at the 2010 Academy of Country Music Awards.

paragraphs.title: Floria Márquez
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Márquez has also performed more than 34 concerts with several symphony orchestras in Venezuela, a privilege granted to few popular artists in her country. She performs an average of 70 shows each year.

paragraphs.title: Me and Tennessee
paragraphs.paragraph_text: "Me and Tennessee" is a song written by Chris Martin and performed by Tim McGraw and Gwyneth Paltrow. It is included on the soundtrack to the 2010 film "Country Strong", in which the two star. It peaked at number 34 on the U.S. "Billboard" Hot Country Songs chart and at number 63 on the UK Singles chart.

paragraphs.title: All My Rowdy Friends Are Coming Over Tonight
paragraphs.paragraph_text: "All My Rowdy Friends Are Coming Over Tonight" is a song written and recorded by American country music performer Hank Williams Jr. It was released in October 1984 as the second single from his album "Major Moves". It peaked at number ten on the country music charts. From 1989 to 2011 Williams performed a version of the song (reworked as "All My Rowdy Friends Are Here on Monday Night") as the opening theme to "Monday Night Football". The song was reinstated in 2017, with a new version by Williams Jr., Florida Georgia Line and Jason Derulo.

paragraphs.title: Kanye West
paragraphs.paragraph_text: In September 2013, West was widely rebuked by human rights groups for performing in Kazakhstan at the wedding of authoritarian President Nursultan Nazarbayev's grandson. He traveled to Kazakhstan, which has one of the poorest human rights records in the world, as a personal guest of Nazarbayev. Other notable Western performers, including Sting, have previously cancelled performances in the country over human rights concerns. West was reportedly paid US$3 million for his performance. West had previously participated in cultural boycotts, joining Shakira and Rage Against The Machine in refusing to perform in Arizona after the 2010 implementation of stop and search laws directed against potential illegal aliens.

paragraphs.title: Friends in Low Places
paragraphs.paragraph_text: ``Friends in Low Places ''is a song performed by American country pop artist Garth Brooks. It was released on August 6, 1990 as the lead single from his album No Fences. The song spent four weeks at number one on the Hot Country Songs, and won both the Academy of Country Music and Country Music Association awards for 1990 Single of the Year.

paragraphs.title: She Can't Say That Anymore
paragraphs.paragraph_text: "She Can't Say That Anymore" is a song written by Sonny Throckmorton and recorded by American country music performer John Conlee. It was released in September 1980 as the second single from the album "Friday Night Blues". The song reached #2 on the "Billboard" Hot Country Singles & Tracks chart.

output.answer:
Hey, one I can answer! 

First off, the "information" that enters a tube is not audio, it is just an electrical signal. 

The internal components of a vacuum tube are the cathode, anode, grid, and heating element.  The small signal (~mv) that needs to be amplified enters the tube via the grid, which rests between the cathode and anode which are both coated with a material that encourages electron flow. The anode is positively charged with a much higher voltage than the grid, while the cathode is negatively charged. As the small signal hits the grid it creates a fluctuation in the large flow of electrons between the cathode and anode, thus amplifying the signal. The heating element is used to promote the flow of electrons, while keeping the components in a vacuum both promotes electron flow and reduces component wear to to oxidation.  

Source: I build guitar amps. 

tl;dr Small signal modulates big signal.

llama13b_without_search_answer:
Audio vacuum tubes, also known as thermionic valves, are electronic devices that use a heated filament to emit electrons, which are then amplified to produce sound. They were widely used in early audio equipment, such as radios and amplifiers, but have largely been replaced by solid-state devices. However, they are still used in some high-end audio equipment and by audiophiles for their unique sound characteristics.

There are several types of audio vacuum tubes, including:

1. Triode: This is the most common type of vacuum tube and consists of three electrodes - a cathode, a grid, and a plate. The cathode emits electrons when heated, which are then amplified by the grid and plate.
2. Pentode: This type of tube has a additional grid, known as the screen grid, which helps to control the flow of electrons.
3. Tetrode: This type of tube has a screen grid like a pentode, but the screen grid is not connected to the plate.
4. Power tube: This type of tube is designed to handle high power and is typically used in high-power amplifiers.
5. Pre-amp tube: This type of tube is used in pre-amplifiers and is designed to amplify low-level signals.
6. Output tube: This type of tube is used in power amplifiers and is designed to drive a load, such as a speaker.

The advantages of using vacuum tubes in audio equipment include:

1. Warm, rich sound: Vacuum tubes are known for producing a warm, full-bodied sound that is often described as more "natural" or "organic" than the sound produced by solid-state devices.
2. High input impedance: Vacuum tubes have a high input impedance, which means they can handle a wide range of input levels without distorting the signal.
3. Low output impedance: Vacuum tubes have a low output impedance, which means they can drive a load, such as a speaker, with a high current.
4. High linearity: Vacuum tubes are highly linear, meaning that the output signal is directly proportional to the input signal.
5. Low noise: Vacuum tubes are relatively low noise devices

output.answer:
*Depth of field* is basically the area of your vision that is in focus. The human eye automatically adjusts the our DoF when we focus on something, much like a point-and-shoot digital camera. Hold up your hand about 10cm in front of your face and look at it. Notice how everything in the background is blurry and out of focus? Now hold your hand out as far as you can and look at it, -the background should be a little fuzzy but not to the same extent as it was before. Now as you read this sentence, hold your hand up in front of your face but continue looking at these words, -your hand will be out of focus.

Try to visualize your sight as a straight line from your eye to a point 1 kilometre away, kind of like [this](_URL_0_). Now when you're looking at things close to your face, your depth of field will be very 'shallow', or thin. The only area that will be in focus is from about 5cm away from your nose to 10cm away from your nose, -a 5cm wide DoF. As the object you are focusing on moves further away from your face, the width or the DoF surrounding it will grow gradually wider. The DoF surrounding your hands at arms length will stretch to about 10cm in front of and behind of your hands. When you're focusing on a chair five metres away, the DoF will stretch from 50cm in front of the object to 50cm behind, and so on. The depth of field gets bigger and bigger as we look at things that are further away, so when we look out at a mountain range, pretty much everything from 30 metres to infinity is in focus.

Now look at the 'tilt-shift' photos once more, and take note of what the focus, or DoF is like. Really shallow, right? *Just as we were holding it in front of our noses*! Basically, these 'miniature fakes', as they are sometimes called, work by presenting a scene that would normally be completely clear and sharp to the human eye with only a thin slice of focus. Because of how we are used to viewing the world, the brain says 'well obviously that's not a large scene, if it were it would be in focus', and draws the conclusion that it must be very miniature and diorama-sized. I guess you could say that it's a kind of illusion.

The way this shallow depth of field is achieved is by physically tilting the lens so that it's at an angle to the camera, which changes the shape of the depth of field and introduces some other concepts like the *plane of focus* and the *Scheimpflug principle*. It's pretty complex, and to be honest, I don't fully understand it. You can't do it with normal camera lenses though, you need ones that can bend themselves. Realistically though, 95% percent of the ones you see online have probably been artificially created in photoshop, as tilt-shift lenses are very expensive and the effect is hard to achieve, whereas it is relatively easy to fake. Here's some 
[before](_URL_2_) and [after](_URL_1_) shots of someone faking the effect on a computer. It's also important to note that no shift (vertical bending of the lens) is involved at all, only tilt (horizontal bend). Thus the name of the style is largely irrelevant and misinforming, I kind of resent that...

Tilt Shift lenses do not create any shallower depth of field than regular lenses, the term 'tilt-shift' photography is a misnomer, it is a misuse of the functions to create these effects, and is simply throwing the top and bottom of the image out of focus by rotating the plane of focus to be nearly perpendicular to the sensor plane.

Depth of field (or depth of focus) in reality (and poorly imitated by the 'tilt-shift effect) is caused by the lens.  Light is projected through the lens from the scene, and the scene in essence is reduced in size to fit the sensor.

The lens can only focus at one plane 'cut' through the image at a time, focusing 'moves' this reproduced scene through the focus point.  Light that is *not* focused (further beyond or in front of the focused plane) is blurry because the point of light has not resolved to a fine point yet (or already has, and is diverging again by the time it hits the sensor).

Shallow Depth of focus is caused by increasing the 'size' of that blurriness or defocus so that it is bigger when it hits the sensor, making the focused and unfocused points more dramatically different.  There is never a real deeper depth of focus, but by making the defocussed points 'smaller' instead of larger, more of the scene is rendered with points smaller than the sensor can resolve, making more appear in focus.

Depth of field (DOF) is a photography term that refers to the range of distance in a scene that appears to be acceptably sharp and in focus. It is a measure of how much of the image is rendered as a "sharp" or "acceptably focused" area, and how much falls into the background or foreground.

In other words, depth of field determines how much of the scene is in focus, from the foreground to the background. A large depth of field means that most of the scene is in focus, while a small depth of field means that only a small portion of the scene is in focus, with the rest falling out of focus.

The depth of field is controlled by the camera's aperture, which is the opening in the lens that lets light pass through to the sensor. A larger aperture (smaller f-number) will result in a shallower depth of field, while a smaller aperture (larger f-number) will result in a deeper depth of field.

Here's how it works:

1. The aperture of the camera controls the amount of light that enters the lens and reaches the sensor.
2. The aperture also controls the size of the depth of field, with a larger aperture resulting in a shallower depth of field and a smaller aperture resulting in a deeper depth of field.
3. The depth of field is determined by the distance between the subject and the camera, as well as the focal length of the lens.
4. As the aperture gets larger, the depth of field decreases, meaning that only a small portion of the scene will be in focus.
5. Conversely, as the aperture gets smaller, the depth of field increases, meaning that more of the scene will be in focus.
6. The point of focus is the point at which the subject is in sharpest focus, and this point will be located at a certain distance from the camera.
7. The depth of field extends a certain distance before and after the point of focus, and this distance is determined by the aperture and the focal length of the lens.
8. The depth of field can be manipulated by adjusting the aperture, focal length, and distance of the subject from the camera.

question: What type of moss typically grows on Live Oak and Cypress trees?
llama13b_without_search_answer:
Live oak (Quercus virginiana) and cypress (Taxodium distichum) trees are both native to the southeastern United States, and they support a variety of mosses. Here are some of the most common types of mosses that grow on these trees:

1. Southern shaggy moss (Epiphyllum portulacastrum): This moss is a common epiphyte on live oaks and cypress trees in the southeastern United States. It has long, shaggy branches and a soft, feathery texture.
2. Christmas moss (Hypnum andromedae): This moss is a popular choice for holiday decorations due to its bright green color and feathery texture. It grows on the branches of live oaks and cypress trees in the southeast.
3. Wiregrass moss (Aristida beyrichii): This moss is a low-growing, dense moss that forms thick mats on the trunks and branches of live oaks and cypress trees. It has a wire-like texture and a dark green color.
4. Rough-stalked feather moss (Plagiobothrys hyperboreus): This moss has long, rough stalks and a soft, feathery texture. It grows on the branches of live oaks and cypress trees in the southeastern United States.
5. Mood moss (Bryum spp.): This moss is a common epiphyte on live oaks and cypress trees in the southeast. It has a soft, spongy texture and a bright green color.
6. Star moss (Ceratodon spp.): This moss has a star-shaped habit and grows on the branches of live oaks and cypress trees in the southeastern United States. It has a soft, feathery texture and a bright green color.
7. Bristly moss (Grimmia spp.): This moss has long, bristly branches and a soft, feathery texture. It grows on the trunks and branches of live oaks and cypress trees in the southeastern United States.

These are just a few examples of the many types of mosses that can grow on live oak and cypress trees

qa_pairs.context: In 2015, the Packers lost wide receiver Jordy Nelson to a torn ACL in the preseason. The Packers got off to a 6-0 start, but then went 1-4 to sit at 7-4 after Week 12. During Week 13 at Detroit, after trailing 20-0 in the second half, Aaron Rodgers threw a 61-yard Hail Mary pass to tight end Richard Rodgers with no time left on the clock to win the game 27-23 after a facemask penalty was called on Detroit as time expired. The Packers clinched their seventh consecutive playoff berth with a Week 15 win at the Oakland Raiders, but lost the division title to the Vikings in Week 17. With a 10-6 record, the Packers secured the fifth seed in the playoffs. They beat the fourth-seeded Washington Redskins on the road 35-18 and traveled to face the second-seeded Arizona Cardinals. A similar play to what happened in Week 13 at Detroit occurred in the last 5 seconds when Aaron Rodgers threw a Hail Mary pass to wide receiver Jeff Janis to send the game to overtime. Unfortunately, the Packers' season ended when they lost to the Cardinals 26-20 in overtime.

qa_pairs.question: When did color tv come out for public demonstration in a public building what year?
qa_pairs.context: During its campaign for FCC approval, CBS gave the first demonstrations of color television to the general public, showing an hour of color programs daily Mondays through Saturdays, beginning January 12, 1950, and running for the remainder of the month, over WOIC in Washington, D.C., where the programs could be viewed on eight 16-inch color receivers in a public building. Due to high public demand, the broadcasts were resumed February 13–21, with several evening programs added. CBS initiated a limited schedule of color broadcasts from its New York station WCBS-TV Mondays to Saturdays beginning November 14, 1950, making ten color receivers available for the viewing public. All were broadcast using the single color camera that CBS owned. The New York broadcasts were extended by coaxial cable to Philadelphia's WCAU-TV beginning December 13, and to Chicago on January 10, making them the first network color broadcasts.

qa_pairs.question: When did color tv come out for retail purchase what year?
qa_pairs.context: While the CBS color broadcasting schedule gradually expanded to twelve hours per week (but never into prime time), and the color network expanded to eleven affiliates as far west as Chicago, its commercial success was doomed by the lack of color receivers necessary to watch the programs, the refusal of television manufacturers to create adapter mechanisms for their existing black-and-white sets, and the unwillingness of advertisers to sponsor broadcasts seen by almost no one. CBS had bought a television manufacturer in April, and in September 1951, production began on the only CBS-Columbia color television model, with the first color sets reaching retail stores on September 28. But it was too little, too late. Only 200 sets had been shipped, and only 100 sold, when CBS discontinued its color television system on October 20, 1951, ostensibly by request of the National Production Authority for the duration of the Korean War, and bought back all the CBS color sets it could to prevent lawsuits by disappointed customers. RCA chairman David Sarnoff later charged that the NPA's order had come "out of a situation artificially created by one company to solve its own perplexing problems" because CBS had been unsuccessful in its color venture.

qa_pairs.question: When did the first practical demo of a mechanically-scanned color tv come out what year?
qa_pairs.context: Transmission of color images using mechanical scanners had been conceived as early as the 1880s. A practical demonstration of mechanically-scanned color television was given by John Logie Baird in 1928, but the limitations of a mechanical system were apparent even then. Development of electronic scanning and display made an all-electronic system possible. Early monochrome transmission standards were developed prior to the Second World War, but civilian electronics developments were frozen during much of the war. In August 1944, Baird gave the world's first demonstration of a practical fully electronic color television display. In the United States, commercially competing color standards were developed, finally resulting in the NTSC standard for color that retained compatibility with the prior monochrome system. Although the NTSC color standard was proclaimed in 1953 and limited programming became available, it was not until the early 1970s that color television in North America outsold black and white or monochrome units. Color broadcasting in Europe was not standardized on the PAL and SECAM formats until the 1960s.

Color television was first introduced in the late 1940s and early 1950s. The first public demonstration of a color television system was held in London in 1928, but it wasn't until the 1950s that color TV became widely available to the public.

In the United States, the first color TV broadcasts began in 1954, with the first color TV sets going on sale in 1955. The first color TV broadcasts were in the NTSC (National Television System Committee) format, which was developed by the FCC (Federal Communications Commission) in the United States.

Here are some key dates related to the development and introduction of color TV:

* 1928: First public demonstration of a color television system in London
* 1940s: Research and development of color TV technology begins in the United States and Europe
* 1950s: Color TV broadcasts begin in the United States and Europe
* 1954: First color TV broadcasts in the United States, using the NTSC format
* 1955: First color TV sets go on sale in the United States
* 1960s: Color TV becomes widely available and affordable for the general public

It's worth noting that other countries also developed their own color TV systems, such as the PAL (Phase Alternating Line) system used in Europe and Australia, and the SECAM (Séquentiel couleur à mémoire) system used in France and other countries.

output.answer:
Stored body fat is the body's way of preparing for famine. It locks away energy in a form it knows it can carry around for as long as it needs to, and then access quickly when the need arises. Your body only gets rid of fat when it has to. Our bodies really like surviving and it's tell DNA about how cheap hot pockets are.

So the body only uses up fat when it absolutely has to. That means when there are fewer calories coming in than being used in a day. It seems a horrifying thought at first, not eating enough to keep your body going. BUT THAT'S NOT WHAT'S HAPPENING! 

If you're running and it's going to burn 300 hundred calories, but you've only eat 200 that day, you're body isn't going to stop you as soon as you've burned that 200 you ate. It prioritizes keeping you going, so it start using that energy store we talked about. Your fat. Do that enough, for long enough, and all the stored fat is used up. New fat is only added when we eat OVER what we use that day.

However, fat only gives the body energy. It isn't adding any nutrients to the mix. Your body needs those too. It's fine to cut way down on your calorie intake for a day or two, but then come close to regular to bring in the nutrients your body is craving. 

I'm 5'9" 22 year old guy, so my caloric requirement for a day is right around 2000 calories. To lose weight I may do a week of eating like this.

Monday: 1900 calories
Tuesday: 1300 calories
Wednesday: 1500 Calories
Thursday: 1900 calories
Friday: 1000 calories
Saturday: 1400 calories
Sunday is your cheat day, eat whatever you feel like tubby. (Within reason. I'm calling myself tubby here.)


Loose skin is a harder problem. Younger people have an easier time with this. Our bodies respond faster and heal more quickly so skin will tighten somewhat on it's own. Even stretch marks will go away after a decade or so.

The important thing to take away from this is that on it's own the body will NOT recover from being over weight. Even if you stop eating too much, your body won't dip into it's energy stores unless you show it you need it to. And you need to show it a lot because our metabolisms are super dumb and may take months to recognize we don't need to keep shoveling in energy for later. Keep up the good fight bud. Find a way to keep yourself accountable like posting in /r/loseit/ or starting a tumblr for your weight lose journey (which I prefer to call 'getting sexy journey') Even if no one follows you or offers sex for your increasingly more attractive physique, this will help you establish a schedule which is crucial in losing those extra pounds.

llama13b_without_search_answer:
The human body is capable of recovering from being overweight, but it requires a combination of healthy lifestyle changes and patience. Here are some steps you can take to help your body recover from being overweight:

1. Lose weight gradually: Crash diets and rapid weight loss are not sustainable and can be harmful to your health. Instead, aim to lose 1-2 pounds per week for a healthy and sustainable weight loss.
2. Eat a balanced diet: Focus on consuming whole, unprocessed foods such as vegetables, fruits, whole grains, lean proteins, and healthy fats. Avoid sugary drinks, processed meats, and high-calorie snacks.
3. Increase physical activity: Regular exercise can help you burn calories, build muscle, and improve your overall health. Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise per week.
4. Strength training: Building muscle through strength training can help you burn more calories at rest and improve your overall health. Aim for 2-3 strength training sessions per week.
5. Get enough sleep: Poor sleep can disrupt hormones that regulate hunger and fullness, leading to overeating and weight gain. Aim for 7-9 hours of sleep per night.
6. Manage stress: Chronic stress can lead to overeating and weight gain. Try stress-reducing techniques such as meditation, yoga, or deep breathing exercises.
7. Stay hydrated: Drinking enough water can help suppress appetite and improve digestion. Aim for at least 8 cups (64 ounces) of water per day.
8. Monitor your progress: Regularly tracking your weight, body fat percentage, and measurements can help you stay motivated and see the progress you're making.
9. Seek professional help: If you're struggling with obesity or weight-related health issues, consider seeking help from a healthcare professional such as a registered dietitian or a certified personal trainer.
10. Be patient: Losing weight and recovering from obesity takes time

paragraphs.title: Portugal
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Pelayos' plan was to use the Cantabrian mountains as a place of refuge and protection from the invading Moors. He then aimed to regroup the Iberian Peninsula's Christian armies and use the Cantabrian mountains as a springboard from which to regain their lands from the Moors. In the process, after defeating the Moors in the Battle of Covadonga in 722 AD, Pelayos was proclaimed king, thus founding the Christian Kingdom of Asturias and starting the war of Christian reconquest known in Portuguese as the Reconquista Cristã.

paragraphs.title: Asterix and the Secret Weapon
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Asterix and the Secret Weapon is the twenty-ninth volume of the Asterix comic book series and the fifth by Albert Uderzo alone. It parodies feminism, gender equality/relationships, and military secrets.

paragraphs.title: Eritrean Air Force
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The Eritrean Air Force (ERAF) is the official aerial warfare service branch of the Eritrean Defence Forces and is one of the three official uniformed military branches of the State of Eritrea.

paragraphs.title: Live and Let Die (film)
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Live and Let Die is a 1973 British spy film, the eighth in the "James Bond" series to be produced by Eon Productions, and the first to star Roger Moore as the fictional MI6 agent James Bond. Produced by Albert R. Broccoli and Harry Saltzman, it was the third of four Bond films to be directed by Guy Hamilton. Although the producers had wanted Sean Connery to return after his role in the previous Bond film "Diamonds Are Forever", he declined, sparking a search for a new actor to play James Bond. Moore was signed for the lead role.

paragraphs.title: East Prussia
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The Teutonic Order lost eastern Prussia when Grand Master Albert of Brandenburg-Ansbach converted to Lutheranism and secularized the Prussian branch of the Teutonic Order in 1525. Albert established himself as the first duke of the Duchy of Prussia and a vassal of the Polish crown by the Prussian Homage. Walter von Cronberg, the next Grand Master, was enfeoffed with the title to Prussia after the Diet of Augsburg in 1530, but the Order never regained possession of the territory. In 1569 the Hohenzollern prince-electors of the Margraviate of Brandenburg became co-regents with Albert's son, the feeble-minded Albert Frederick.

paragraphs.title: Albert Wolfgang of Brandenburg-Bayreuth
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Albert Wolfgang of Brandenburg-Bayreuth (8 December 1689 in Sulzbürg, now part of Mühlhausen – 29 June 1734 in Parma) was a Margrave of Brandenburg-Bayreuth from the Kulmbach-Bayreuth side line of Franconian branch of the House of Hohenzollern. He served as a general in the imperial army.

paragraphs.title: Albert Nofi
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Albert A. Nofi (born January 6, 1944), is an American military historian, defense analyst, and designer of board and computer wargaming systems.

paragraphs.title: Republic of China Military Police
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The Republic of China Military Police (ROCMP; ) is a military police body under the Ministry of National Defense of Taiwan (Republic of China). Unlike military police in many other countries, ROCMP is a separate branch of the ROC Armed Forces. ROCMP is responsible for protecting government leaders from assassination or capture, guarding Taiwan’s strategic facilities, and counterintelligence against enemy infiltrators, spies, and saboteurs.

paragraphs.title: The Singular Life of Albert Nobbs
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The Singular Life of Albert Nobbs (French: "La Vie singulière d'Albert Nobbs") is a play by French author Simone Benmussa. Based on a novella by George Moore, the drama tells the story of a 19th-century woman who disguises herself as a man to avoid poverty. The role of Albert Nobbs was originated by French actress Juliet Berto. The drama premiered in November 1977 at the Théâtre d'Orsay in Paris.

paragraphs.title: Bustec
paragraphs.paragraph_text: Bustec was founded in 1997, in Ireland by Dr. Fred Bloennigen, current CEO. In 2000 the company opened its branch in the USA.

paragraphs.title: United States Air Force
paragraphs.paragraph_text: The United States Air Force (USAF) is the aerial warfare service branch of the United States Armed Forces and one of the seven American uniformed services. Initially part of the United States Army, the USAF was formed as a separate branch of the military on 18 September 1947 under the National Security Act of 1947. It is the most recent branch of the U.S. military to be formed, and is the largest and one of the world's most technologically advanced air forces. The USAF articulates its core functions as Nuclear Deterrence Operations, Special Operations, Air Superiority, Global Integrated ISR, Space Superiority, Command and Control, Cyberspace Superiority, Personnel Recovery, Global Precision Attack, Building Partnerships, Rapid Global Mobility and Agile Combat Support.

Father Serra arrived in California in 1769 and began building the first Spanish missions in the region. He founded nine missions in total, including Mission San Luis Rey de Francia, which was the largest of all the California missions. The mission was built in the village of Pamo, which is now known as Oceanside, California.

Other notable figures who helped build and maintain Mission San Luis Rey de Francia include:

1. Fray Antonio Peyri: Peyri was a Spanish Franciscan friar who served as the first assistant to Father Serra and helped him establish the mission.
2. Fray Juan Crespí: Crespí was a Spanish Franciscan friar who served as the mission's chronicler and helped document the early history of the mission.
3. Fray Thomas Akainza: Akainza was a Spanish Franciscan friar who helped build and maintain the mission.
4. Indian laborers: Many Native Americans from the local Kumeyaay tribe were forced to work as laborers on the mission, helping to build the buildings and tend to the crops.
5. Spanish soldiers: Spanish soldiers were stationed at the mission to protect the priests and the Native American laborers from potential attacks by other Native American tribes or European rivals.

output.answer: Surprisingly, a bullet through the head insufficiently guarantees both death and painlessness. I also expect the perception of relative barbarism between shooting someone in the head, and killing them in some quiet fashion, plays a role.

Aside from the "we like to pretend we are civilized and humane" which I very much agree with, another aspect is that although many people feel capital punishment is warranted, when it gets down to doing the deed, you are killing a human being.  Seemed easy when the bureaucracy set it in motion with some euphemistic rhetoric on paper, but killing someone is something we are (for the lack of a better word) *weird* about.  It makes us feel things.  What we end up doing is *ritualizing* the event.  Because we are weird about it, we tend to build a ritualized ceremony around it, where the person might say some words, get a last meal, have spectators gather in a designated area, do the deed and say some more words. With the ceremony of a socially validated ritual built around it, we can disassociate from the personal responsibility of performing the action. 

This is why we dont "just" shoot someone in the head.  Although I can see us ceremoniously using a firing squad.

Just use nitrogen.  It's 78% of our atmosphere, so it is plentiful. It fills up your lungs so oxygen can't get in.  It also lets your body expel the carbon dioxide when you breath out, so the CO2 doesn't build up in your blood, causing the pain related to suffocation.

Cheap and mess free.

People are squicky about body trauma; if you leave a body messy, that's barbaric, even though the dead person probably doesn't know the difference.   I've often advocated sudden, massive crushing blow to the skull, flattening the brain before it can understand what's happening -- no chance of surviving or a near-miss -- but destroying the head really creeps people out.  Also, *ease* of doing it bothers people; consider the French Revolution, once people realized how easy it is to behead those they disagree with, things got bad.  When you have execution as relatively complex and scientific processes there's less opportunity to do it willy-nilly.
I like the idea of a [Euthanasia Coaster](_URL_0_)
Because we like to think we are above that kind of barbarism. The same reason why we just don't shoot people who are in a vegetative state, or people who are terminally ill.

The question I have is, in the case of murderers, rapists and the like, why are we all so concerned about making sure that they have a completely painless, fast execution? The same that was denied to their victims?
I think that everyone's overlooking that a shot to head would eliminate the possibility of an open casket funeral. I'm sure it's not the only reason, but it makes sense.

I'm sorry, but most on everyone here seems to be very cynical about how far human societies have come from the depths of barbarism. Like its a scale-able model. More to the point, though, look at world war 1 and 2, and ask why they used a firing 'squad' rather than a lone officer with a revolver? Why not let their CO do the deed, to fit with this concept of ceremony? 

I suppose ceremony has something to do with it. But really, its so the people who are committing this murder can go home and be able to look themselves in the mirror. It absolves the participants of guilt because (hopefully) no one knows who did it, coupled with the function of an assured kill of course. Fast forward, and now you have a very clinical process, which absolves the good guys of a large degree of guilt and remorse whilst still achieving the same end state.
We should just have them breathe inert gas... painless, and guaranteed death.

question: Why don't we just shoot people who are on death row, instead of going through the trouble of concocting different types of injections?
long_answers: Surprisingly, a bullet through the head insufficiently guarantees both death and painlessness. I also expect the perception of relative barbarism between shooting someone in the head, and killing them in some quiet fashion, plays a role.
